name: Phishing Email Detection
description: Learn to identify phishing emails, suspicious links, and fraudulent sender addresses. This module covers common phishing tactics used by cybercriminals.

questions.title: You receive an email from 'security@amaz0n-support.com' asking you to verify your account. What should you do?
options: Click the link and verify your account
Forward it to your IT department and delete it
Ignore it but keep it in your inbox
questions.correct_answer: Forward it to your IT department and delete it
questions.explanation: The domain 'amaz0n-support.com' uses a zero instead of 'o' - a common phishing tactic. Always report suspicious emails to IT.

questions.title: Which of the following is a red flag in a phishing email?
questions.correct_answer: Urgent language demanding immediate action
questions.explanation: Phishing emails often create urgency to make you act without thinking. Legitimate companies rarely demand immediate action.

questions.title: An email claims your Netflix account will be suspended in 24 hours unless you update payment info. The link goes to 'netfliix-billing.com'. What's wrong?
options: Nothing, Netflix often sends these emails
The domain has an extra 'i' - it's a fake site
24 hours is too long of a timeframe
questions.correct_answer: The domain has an extra 'i' - it's a fake site
questions.explanation: Typosquatting uses misspelled domains like 'netfliix' instead of 'netflix' to trick users.

questions.title: What is the safest way to verify if an email from your bank is legitimate?
options: Click the link in the email to check
Call the number provided in the email
Log into your bank account directly through their official website
Reply to the email asking for confirmation
questions.correct_answer: Log into your bank account directly through their official website
questions.explanation: Never use links or phone numbers from suspicious emails. Always navigate directly to the official website.

questions.title: You receive an email with an attachment named 'Invoice_12345.pdf.exe'. What should you do?
options: Open it to see the invoice details
Rename it to remove .exe and open it
Delete it immediately - .exe files are executable programs
questions.correct_answer: Delete it immediately - .exe files are executable programs
questions.explanation: Double extensions like '.pdf.exe' hide malicious executables. Real PDFs never end in .exe.

questions.title: Which email header information can help identify a phishing attempt?
options: The 'Reply-To' address differs from the 'From' address
The date the email was sent
questions.correct_answer: The 'Reply-To' address differs from the 'From' address
questions.explanation: When Reply-To differs from From, responses go to a different address - often an attacker's inbox.

questions.title: A colleague's email asks you to wire $5,000 urgently for a business deal. The email looks legitimate. What should you do?
options: Call your colleague directly using a known phone number to verify
Reply to the email asking for more details
Check if the amount matches your budget
questions.correct_answer: Call your colleague directly using a known phone number to verify
questions.explanation: Business Email Compromise (BEC) attacks spoof or compromise colleague accounts. Always verify financial requests via a separate channel.

questions.title: What is 'spear phishing'?
options: Phishing targeted at specific individuals using personal information
questions.correct_answer: Phishing targeted at specific individuals using personal information
questions.explanation: Spear phishing uses personalized information to make attacks more convincing and targeted.

questions.title: An email from 'IT Support' asks for your password to fix a system issue. How should you respond?
options: Provide your password - IT needs it to help
Ask them to call you first
Never share your password - legitimate IT never asks for it
Send it in a separate email for security
questions.correct_answer: Never share your password - legitimate IT never asks for it
questions.explanation: Legitimate IT departments never ask for passwords via email. This is always a phishing attempt.

questions.title: What does 'HTTPS' in a URL indicate?
options: The website is 100% safe and legitimate
The connection is encrypted, but the site could still be malicious
The website is owned by the government
questions.correct_answer: The connection is encrypted, but the site could still be malicious
questions.explanation: HTTPS means encrypted connection, not a legitimate website. Phishing sites can also use HTTPS.

questions.title: You hover over a link in an email and see it goes to 'bit.ly/abc123'. What should you do?
options: Click it - shortened URLs are safe
Avoid clicking - URL shorteners can hide malicious destinations
Copy and paste it into your browser
Click it only if the email looks professional
questions.correct_answer: Avoid clicking - URL shorteners can hide malicious destinations
questions.explanation: URL shorteners hide the true destination. Legitimate businesses rarely use them in official communications.

questions.title: What is 'whaling' in cybersecurity?
options: Phishing attacks targeting executives and high-level employees
questions.correct_answer: Phishing attacks targeting executives and high-level employees
questions.explanation: Whaling targets 'big fish' - executives who have access to sensitive data and financial authority.

questions.title: An email contains perfect grammar, company branding, and your full name. Can it still be phishing?
options: No, phishing emails always have errors
Yes, sophisticated phishing can look completely legitimate
No, scammers don't have access to personal information
Only if it asks for money
questions.correct_answer: Yes, sophisticated phishing can look completely legitimate
questions.explanation: Advanced phishing attacks use stolen data and professional design. Don't rely on appearance alone.

questions.title: What should you check when you receive an unexpected email attachment?
options: Sender's email address, file type, and whether you expected it
questions.correct_answer: Sender's email address, file type, and whether you expected it
questions.explanation: Always verify the sender, check file extensions, and confirm you were expecting the attachment.

questions.title: What is a 'homograph attack'?
options: Using similar-looking characters from different alphabets to fake URLs
Sending identical emails to multiple people
questions.correct_answer: Using similar-looking characters from different alphabets to fake URLs
questions.explanation: Homograph attacks use characters like Cyrillic 'Ð°' that look identical to Latin 'a' to create fake URLs.

questions.title: You receive a job offer email with an amazing salary for a position you didn't apply for. What's the likely scenario?
options: A recruiter found your resume online
It's probably a scam to collect personal information
You should respond to learn more
Forward it to HR to verify
questions.correct_answer: It's probably a scam to collect personal information
questions.explanation: Unsolicited job offers with unrealistic salaries are commonly used to harvest personal data or install malware.

questions.title: What technique do attackers use when they register domains like 'g00gle.com'?
questions.correct_answer: Typosquatting
questions.explanation: Typosquatting involves registering misspelled versions of popular domains to catch typing errors or trick users.

questions.title: An email claims to be from Microsoft and includes a link to 'microsoft.com.malicious-site.com'. Is this legitimate?
options: No, the actual domain is malicious-site.com
questions.correct_answer: No, the actual domain is malicious-site.com
questions.explanation: The actual domain is always before the first single slash. 'microsoft.com' here is a subdomain of 'malicious-site.com'.

questions.title: What is 'clone phishing'?
options: Copying a legitimate email and replacing links with malicious ones
Sending the same email multiple times
questions.correct_answer: Copying a legitimate email and replacing links with malicious ones
questions.explanation: Clone phishing duplicates real emails but replaces links or attachments with malicious versions.

questions.title: Why do phishing emails often have spelling errors?
options: To filter out cautious users who would report the attack
questions.correct_answer: To filter out cautious users who would report the attack
questions.explanation: Intentional errors filter out vigilant users, leaving targets more likely to fall for the full scam.

name: Social Engineering Defense
description: Understand manipulation tactics including pretexting, baiting, tailgating, and psychological manipulation used by attackers to gain unauthorized access.

questions.title: Someone calls claiming to be from IT and asks for your password to 'verify your account'. What should you do?
options: Ask for their employee ID and provide the password
Refuse and report the call to your actual IT department
questions.correct_answer: Refuse and report the call to your actual IT department
questions.explanation: Legitimate IT staff never ask for passwords. This is a classic pretexting attack.

questions.title: What is 'pretexting' in social engineering?
options: Creating a fabricated scenario to extract information
questions.correct_answer: Creating a fabricated scenario to extract information
questions.explanation: Pretexting involves creating a fictional scenario (pretext) to manipulate victims into revealing information.

questions.title: A person in a delivery uniform asks you to hold the secure door open. What should you do?
options: Hold the door - they're clearly a delivery person
Ask them to badge in themselves or contact reception
Let them in but follow them
questions.correct_answer: Ask them to badge in themselves or contact reception
questions.explanation: This is 'tailgating'. Uniforms can be faked. Everyone should use their own credentials.

questions.title: What is 'baiting' in social engineering?
options: Leaving infected USB drives in public places
Insulting someone to provoke a response
questions.correct_answer: Leaving infected USB drives in public places
questions.explanation: Baiting exploits curiosity by leaving malware-infected devices where victims will find and use them.

questions.title: Someone claiming to be a vendor requests sensitive company information via phone. How should you verify?
options: Call them back using the official vendor contact number you have on file
Trust them if they know your name
questions.correct_answer: Call them back using the official vendor contact number you have on file
questions.explanation: Always verify using contact information you already have, not information provided by the caller.

questions.title: What psychological principle do attackers exploit when they create urgency?
questions.correct_answer: Scarcity and fear
questions.explanation: Creating urgency exploits scarcity (limited time) and fear (consequences) to bypass rational thinking.

questions.title: A well-dressed person with a visitor badge asks to use your computer 'for just a minute'. What should you do?
options: Let them - they have a badge
Offer to help them find reception or IT
Log out and let them use it
Watch them while they use it
questions.correct_answer: Offer to help them find reception or IT
questions.explanation: Visitor badges don't authorize computer access. Redirect them to proper channels.

questions.title: What is 'quid pro quo' in social engineering?
options: Offering something in exchange for information or access
questions.correct_answer: Offering something in exchange for information or access
questions.explanation: Quid pro quo attacks offer help or rewards in exchange for credentials or sensitive information.

questions.title: Why do social engineers research their targets on social media?
options: To gather personal details for more convincing attacks
Social media is required for attacks
questions.correct_answer: To gather personal details for more convincing attacks
questions.explanation: Social media provides personal details that make pretexts more believable and personalized.

questions.title: What is 'shoulder surfing'?
options: Observing someone's screen or keyboard to steal information
questions.correct_answer: Observing someone's screen or keyboard to steal information
questions.explanation: Shoulder surfing is watching someone enter passwords or view sensitive information.

questions.title: An attacker poses as a new employee and asks for help accessing the network. What principle are they exploiting?
questions.correct_answer: Helpfulness and social obligation
questions.explanation: Attackers exploit our natural desire to help others, especially those who appear vulnerable or new.

questions.title: What is 'vishing'?
questions.correct_answer: Voice phishing via phone calls
questions.explanation: Vishing uses phone calls to trick victims into revealing sensitive information.

questions.title: How can you protect against dumpster diving attacks?
options: Shred all sensitive documents before disposal
questions.correct_answer: Shred all sensitive documents before disposal
questions.explanation: Dumpster diving retrieves discarded documents. Cross-cut shredding prevents reconstruction.

questions.title: What makes authority-based social engineering effective?
options: People naturally comply with perceived authority figures
questions.correct_answer: People naturally comply with perceived authority figures
questions.explanation: The authority principle means people tend to obey perceived authority without questioning.

questions.title: Someone sends you a LinkedIn connection request claiming to work at your company. You don't recognize them. What should you do?
options: Verify their identity through internal channels before accepting
Accept but don't share any information
questions.correct_answer: Verify their identity through internal channels before accepting
questions.explanation: Fake profiles are used for reconnaissance. Verify through HR or internal directory before connecting.

questions.title: What is 'smishing'?
questions.correct_answer: SMS/text message phishing
questions.explanation: Smishing uses SMS text messages to deliver phishing attacks.

questions.title: A caller claims your computer has a virus and offers to fix it remotely. This is likely:
questions.correct_answer: A tech support scam
questions.explanation: Unsolicited tech support calls are scams. Legitimate companies don't cold-call about viruses.

questions.title: Why do attackers often target receptionists and help desk staff?
options: They have access to information and can provide entry points
questions.correct_answer: They have access to information and can provide entry points
questions.explanation: Front-line staff often have access to directories, can transfer calls, and control physical access.

questions.title: What is the best defense against social engineering?
options: Security awareness training and verification procedures
questions.correct_answer: Security awareness training and verification procedures
questions.explanation: Technical controls can't stop social engineering. Training and verification procedures are essential.

questions.title: An attacker uses the 'foot-in-the-door' technique. What does this mean?
options: Starting with a small request before making a larger one
questions.correct_answer: Starting with a small request before making a larger one
questions.explanation: Small initial requests (name, department) make victims more likely to comply with larger requests later.

name: Password Security Best Practices
description: Learn how to create strong passwords, use password managers effectively, and protect your credentials from various attack methods.

questions.title: Which password is the strongest?
questions.correct_answer: correct-horse-battery-staple
questions.explanation: Long passphrases with random words are stronger than short complex passwords. Length beats complexity.

questions.title: How often should you change your password according to modern security guidelines?
options: Only when there's evidence of compromise
questions.correct_answer: Only when there's evidence of compromise
questions.explanation: NIST guidelines now recommend changing passwords only when compromised, as frequent changes lead to weaker passwords.

questions.title: What is a 'credential stuffing' attack?
options: Using leaked credentials from one site to access others
questions.correct_answer: Using leaked credentials from one site to access others
questions.explanation: Credential stuffing uses username/password pairs from data breaches to access other accounts where users reused credentials.

questions.title: Why is password reuse dangerous?
options: It makes passwords easier to remember
If one account is breached, all accounts using that password are vulnerable
questions.correct_answer: If one account is breached, all accounts using that password are vulnerable
questions.explanation: When one service is breached, attackers try those credentials on other services. Unique passwords limit damage.

questions.title: What is the main benefit of using a password manager?
options: They allow you to use unique, complex passwords for every account
questions.correct_answer: They allow you to use unique, complex passwords for every account
questions.explanation: Password managers generate and store unique complex passwords, eliminating the need to remember or reuse them.

questions.title: What is a 'brute force' attack?
questions.correct_answer: Trying every possible password combination
questions.explanation: Brute force systematically tries all possible passwords. Longer passwords exponentially increase the time required.

questions.title: What is a 'dictionary attack'?
options: Using common words and variations as password guesses
Looking up passwords in a dictionary
questions.correct_answer: Using common words and variations as password guesses
questions.explanation: Dictionary attacks try common words, phrases, and predictable patterns (like Password1!) before brute force.

questions.title: Which is the safest way to store passwords?
options: Written on a sticky note under your keyboard
In a text file on your desktop
In a reputable password manager with a strong master password
In your browser's built-in password saver
questions.correct_answer: In a reputable password manager with a strong master password
questions.explanation: Dedicated password managers offer better security features than browser storage or physical notes.

questions.title: What minimum password length is recommended for strong security?
questions.correct_answer: 12-16 characters or more
questions.explanation: Modern recommendations suggest at least 12-16 characters. Longer passphrases are even better.

questions.title: What is 'password spraying'?
options: Trying a few common passwords against many accounts
Using spray paint to hide passwords
questions.correct_answer: Trying a few common passwords against many accounts
questions.explanation: Password spraying tries common passwords across many accounts to avoid lockouts while finding weak passwords.

questions.title: What makes 'Summer2024!' a weak password?
options: It follows a predictable seasonal pattern that attackers know to try
It has too many special characters
questions.correct_answer: It follows a predictable seasonal pattern that attackers know to try
questions.explanation: Attackers know people use seasonal words and years. These patterns are in attack dictionaries.

questions.title: What is 'salting' in password security?
options: Adding random data to passwords before hashing
questions.correct_answer: Adding random data to passwords before hashing
questions.explanation: Salting adds unique random data to each password before hashing, preventing rainbow table attacks.

questions.title: Why shouldn't you use personal information in passwords?
options: Attackers can find this information on social media and use it in targeted attacks
questions.correct_answer: Attackers can find this information on social media and use it in targeted attacks
questions.explanation: Birthdates, pet names, and addresses are easily discoverable and commonly used in targeted attacks.

questions.title: What should you do if you learn a service you use has been breached?
options: Wait for them to contact you
Change your password immediately and any other accounts using the same password
questions.correct_answer: Change your password immediately and any other accounts using the same password
questions.explanation: Act immediately to change compromised credentials and anywhere you've reused them.

questions.title: What is a 'rainbow table' attack?
options: Using precomputed hash values to crack passwords
questions.correct_answer: Using precomputed hash values to crack passwords
questions.explanation: Rainbow tables contain precomputed password hashes to quickly reverse unsalted password hashes.

questions.title: What is a security question's main weakness?
options: Answers are often publicly available or easily guessed
questions.correct_answer: Answers are often publicly available or easily guessed
questions.explanation: Security question answers (mother's maiden name, first pet) are often on social media or public records.

questions.title: How should you answer security questions for maximum security?
options: With false answers stored in your password manager
questions.correct_answer: With false answers stored in your password manager
questions.explanation: Using fictional answers prevents attackers from guessing based on research. Store these in your password manager.

questions.title: What is 'keylogging'?
options: Malware that records keystrokes to capture passwords
questions.correct_answer: Malware that records keystrokes to capture passwords
questions.explanation: Keyloggers record everything typed, capturing passwords even if they're long and complex.

questions.title: What is the purpose of password hashing?
options: To store passwords securely without keeping the actual password
questions.correct_answer: To store passwords securely without keeping the actual password
questions.explanation: Hashing creates a one-way fingerprint. Services verify passwords without storing the actual password.

questions.title: Why should your password manager's master password be memorized, not written down?
options: It provides access to all your passwords - if compromised, everything is at risk
Password managers don't allow written passwords
questions.correct_answer: It provides access to all your passwords - if compromised, everything is at risk
questions.explanation: The master password unlocks all credentials. It must be strong, unique, and memorized.

name: Malicious Ads Recognition
description: Learn to identify malvertising, fake advertisements, and deceptive ad content that can lead to malware or scams.

questions.title: What is 'malvertising'?
options: Malicious code delivered through online advertisements
questions.correct_answer: Malicious code delivered through online advertisements
questions.explanation: Malvertising uses ad networks to distribute malware, sometimes without requiring user clicks.

questions.title: An ad claims 'You've won an iPhone! Click here to claim!' What should you do?
options: Ignore it - unexpected prize notifications are almost always scams
Provide your address to receive it
questions.correct_answer: Ignore it - unexpected prize notifications are almost always scams
questions.explanation: Prize scams are extremely common. Legitimate contests don't announce winners through random ads.

questions.title: What is a 'drive-by download'?
options: Malware that downloads automatically without user consent
questions.correct_answer: Malware that downloads automatically without user consent
questions.explanation: Drive-by downloads exploit browser vulnerabilities to install malware just by visiting a page.

questions.title: An ad says 'Your computer is infected! Download our free antivirus now!' This is likely:
questions.correct_answer: A scareware scam
questions.explanation: Scareware creates fake security alerts to trick users into downloading malware or paying for fake software.

questions.title: How can legitimate websites serve malicious ads?
options: They can't - only sketchy sites have bad ads
Ad networks can be compromised to serve malicious ads on any site
Malicious ads only appear on pirate sites
questions.correct_answer: Ad networks can be compromised to serve malicious ads on any site
questions.explanation: Even reputable sites can serve malicious ads because they use third-party ad networks that can be compromised.

questions.title: What is the safest action when you see a pop-up ad?
options: Click the X button inside the pop-up
Click anywhere on the ad to dismiss it
Close the browser tab or use Task Manager
questions.correct_answer: Close the browser tab or use Task Manager
questions.explanation: Fake X buttons and 'Close' options can trigger downloads. Safely close the tab or use Task Manager.

questions.title: An ad offers a 'free' premium software that normally costs $500. What's the risk?
options: No risk - free software is great
It's likely pirated software bundled with malware
questions.correct_answer: It's likely pirated software bundled with malware
questions.explanation: Free premium software often contains malware, is pirated, or doesn't include promised features.

questions.title: What is 'clickjacking'?
options: Hiding malicious content behind legitimate-looking buttons
questions.correct_answer: Hiding malicious content behind legitimate-looking buttons
questions.explanation: Clickjacking overlays invisible malicious elements over legitimate buttons to capture unintended clicks.

questions.title: How do ad blockers help with security?
options: They reduce exposure to malvertising and tracking
They replace ads with security messages
questions.correct_answer: They reduce exposure to malvertising and tracking
questions.explanation: Ad blockers reduce attack surface by blocking ad networks that could serve malicious content.

questions.title: An ad uses your company's logo and claims to be an official IT update. What should you do?
options: Click it - it must be legitimate
Verify with IT through official channels before taking any action
questions.correct_answer: Verify with IT through official channels before taking any action
questions.explanation: Attackers copy company branding. Always verify updates through official IT channels, not ads.

questions.title: What is 'search ad poisoning'?
options: Malicious ads appearing in search engine results
questions.correct_answer: Malicious ads appearing in search engine results
questions.explanation: Attackers buy search ads for popular software names, leading users to malicious download sites.

questions.title: You search for 'Adobe Reader download' and the first result is an ad. What should you do?
options: Click the ad - it's at the top
Skip ads and go directly to adobe.com
Click any result on the first page
Download from the ad for faster access
questions.correct_answer: Skip ads and go directly to adobe.com
questions.explanation: Search ads can be malicious. Always navigate directly to official websites for software downloads.

questions.title: What makes 'too good to be true' offers dangerous?
options: They typically lead to scams, malware, or data theft
questions.correct_answer: They typically lead to scams, malware, or data theft
questions.explanation: Unrealistic offers exploit greed to lure victims to malicious sites or extract personal information.

questions.title: What is a 'fake download button'?
options: A deceptive ad designed to look like a download button for the content you want
questions.correct_answer: A deceptive ad designed to look like a download button for the content you want
questions.explanation: Fake download buttons trick users into clicking ads that install malware instead of desired content.

questions.title: How can you identify a legitimate download button vs. a fake ad?
options: Hover to check the URL and look for the actual page's download section
The biggest button is always real
questions.correct_answer: Hover to check the URL and look for the actual page's download section
questions.explanation: Hovering reveals the true destination URL. Real download buttons are part of the page, not served from ad networks.

questions.title: An ad claims your Flash Player is outdated and needs updating. What's wrong with this?
options: Adobe discontinued Flash Player in 2020 - this is definitely a scam
questions.correct_answer: Adobe discontinued Flash Player in 2020 - this is definitely a scam
questions.explanation: Flash Player was discontinued in 2020. Any 'Flash update' ad is a malware delivery attempt.

questions.title: What is 'adware'?
options: Unwanted software that displays excessive advertisements
questions.correct_answer: Unwanted software that displays excessive advertisements
questions.explanation: Adware forces ads onto your system, often arriving bundled with free software downloads.

questions.title: Why might a free VPN service actually be dangerous?
options: Free services may collect and sell your data or inject ads
questions.correct_answer: Free services may collect and sell your data or inject ads
questions.explanation: Free VPNs often profit by collecting user data, injecting ads, or even containing malware.

questions.title: What should you do before downloading free software advertised online?
options: Research the software and download only from official sources
questions.correct_answer: Research the software and download only from official sources
questions.explanation: Research software reputation and always download from official websites, not from ads.

questions.title: What is the purpose of deceptive 'system cleaner' ads?
options: To trick users into paying for fake or unnecessary software
questions.correct_answer: To trick users into paying for fake or unnecessary software
questions.explanation: Fake system cleaners exaggerate or fabricate problems to sell unnecessary software or install malware.

name: Data Protection & Privacy
description: Understand data classification, handling sensitive information, privacy regulations, and protecting personal and corporate data.

questions.title: What type of data requires the highest level of protection?
options: Personally Identifiable Information (PII) and financial data
questions.correct_answer: Personally Identifiable Information (PII) and financial data
questions.explanation: PII and financial data have legal protections and severe consequences if breached.

questions.title: What is PII (Personally Identifiable Information)?
options: Data that can identify a specific individual
questions.correct_answer: Data that can identify a specific individual
questions.explanation: PII includes names, SSNs, addresses, and any data that can identify or be traced to an individual.

questions.title: What should you do before emailing sensitive documents externally?
options: Verify recipient, use encryption, and follow data handling policies
questions.correct_answer: Verify recipient, use encryption, and follow data handling policies
questions.explanation: Sensitive data requires verification, encryption, and policy compliance before external sharing.

questions.title: What is the purpose of data classification?
options: To determine appropriate handling and protection levels for different data
questions.correct_answer: To determine appropriate handling and protection levels for different data
questions.explanation: Classification ensures data receives protection appropriate to its sensitivity level.

questions.title: What is GDPR?
options: General Data Protection Regulation - EU privacy law
questions.correct_answer: General Data Protection Regulation - EU privacy law
questions.explanation: GDPR is the European Union's comprehensive data protection and privacy regulation.

questions.title: What is data minimization?
options: Collecting only data necessary for a specific purpose
questions.correct_answer: Collecting only data necessary for a specific purpose
questions.explanation: Data minimization means collecting only what's needed, reducing risk if a breach occurs.

questions.title: How should you dispose of documents containing sensitive information?
options: Cross-cut shredding or secure disposal service
questions.correct_answer: Cross-cut shredding or secure disposal service
questions.explanation: Sensitive documents require secure destruction to prevent dumpster diving attacks.

questions.title: What is encryption's role in data protection?
options: It makes data unreadable without the proper decryption key
questions.correct_answer: It makes data unreadable without the proper decryption key
questions.explanation: Encryption protects data by making it unreadable to unauthorized parties.

questions.title: What should you do if you accidentally send sensitive data to the wrong person?
options: Ignore it and hope they delete it
Report it immediately to your security team and follow incident procedures
Send a follow-up asking them to delete it
Delete the email from your sent folder
questions.correct_answer: Report it immediately to your security team and follow incident procedures
questions.explanation: Data breaches require immediate reporting to enable proper response and compliance with regulations.

questions.title: What is 'data at rest' vs 'data in transit'?
options: Stored data vs data being transmitted over networks
questions.correct_answer: Stored data vs data being transmitted over networks
questions.explanation: Data at rest is stored; data in transit is being transmitted. Both need protection but with different methods.

questions.title: What is a 'data breach'?
options: Unauthorized access, disclosure, or loss of protected data
questions.correct_answer: Unauthorized access, disclosure, or loss of protected data
questions.explanation: A data breach occurs when sensitive data is accessed, disclosed, or lost without authorization.

questions.title: Why is it important to lock your computer when stepping away?
options: To prevent unauthorized access to sensitive information
questions.correct_answer: To prevent unauthorized access to sensitive information
questions.explanation: An unlocked computer allows anyone to access your files, email, and applications.

questions.title: What is the principle of 'least privilege'?
options: Users should only have access to data and systems necessary for their job
questions.correct_answer: Users should only have access to data and systems necessary for their job
questions.explanation: Least privilege limits access to reduce the damage potential if an account is compromised.

questions.title: How should you handle a USB drive found in the parking lot?
options: Plug it in to find the owner
Turn it in to security - never plug in unknown devices
Keep it if no one claims it
Check the contents on a public computer
questions.correct_answer: Turn it in to security - never plug in unknown devices
questions.explanation: Found USB drives may be deliberately planted with malware. Never connect unknown devices.

questions.title: What is 'data retention'?
options: Policies defining how long data is kept before secure deletion
questions.correct_answer: Policies defining how long data is kept before secure deletion
questions.explanation: Data retention policies specify how long data is stored and when it must be securely deleted.

questions.title: What is a privacy impact assessment?
options: An evaluation of how a project affects individual privacy
questions.correct_answer: An evaluation of how a project affects individual privacy
questions.explanation: Privacy impact assessments identify and mitigate privacy risks in new projects or systems.

questions.title: What should you do if a customer asks for all data your company has about them?
options: Forward to your privacy/compliance team - this may be a legal data subject request
questions.correct_answer: Forward to your privacy/compliance team - this may be a legal data subject request
questions.explanation: Under GDPR and similar laws, individuals have rights to access their data. Proper procedures must be followed.

questions.title: What is 'pseudonymization'?
options: Replacing identifying data with artificial identifiers while maintaining data utility
questions.correct_answer: Replacing identifying data with artificial identifiers while maintaining data utility
questions.explanation: Pseudonymization protects identity while allowing data analysis, unlike full anonymization.

questions.title: Why shouldn't you discuss sensitive work information in public places?
options: Eavesdroppers could be competitors, attackers, or journalists
questions.correct_answer: Eavesdroppers could be competitors, attackers, or journalists
questions.explanation: Sensitive conversations in public can be overheard, leading to data leaks or competitive intelligence theft.

questions.title: What is a DPA (Data Processing Agreement)?
options: A contract governing how third parties handle your data
questions.correct_answer: A contract governing how third parties handle your data
questions.explanation: DPAs establish legal requirements for how vendors and partners must protect shared data.

name: Ransomware Awareness
description: Learn how ransomware works, how to prevent infection, and what to do if your systems are compromised by ransomware attacks.

questions.title: What is ransomware?
options: Malware that encrypts files and demands payment for decryption
questions.correct_answer: Malware that encrypts files and demands payment for decryption
questions.explanation: Ransomware encrypts victim files and demands payment (usually cryptocurrency) for the decryption key.

questions.title: What is the most common delivery method for ransomware?
options: Phishing emails with malicious attachments or links
questions.correct_answer: Phishing emails with malicious attachments or links
questions.explanation: Phishing emails are the primary vector, often containing malicious attachments or links to infected sites.

questions.title: Should you pay the ransom if infected with ransomware?
options: Yes, to get files back quickly
No, payment doesn't guarantee file recovery and funds criminal operations
Only if the amount is small
Yes, if you have cyber insurance
questions.correct_answer: No, payment doesn't guarantee file recovery and funds criminal operations
questions.explanation: Payment doesn't guarantee decryption and encourages more attacks. Report to authorities and restore from backups.

questions.title: What is the best protection against ransomware?
options: Regular, tested, offline backups combined with security awareness
questions.correct_answer: Regular, tested, offline backups combined with security awareness
questions.explanation: Tested offline backups allow recovery without paying. Security awareness prevents initial infection.

questions.title: What should you do immediately if you suspect ransomware infection?
options: Disconnect from the network and report to IT immediately
questions.correct_answer: Disconnect from the network and report to IT immediately
questions.explanation: Disconnecting prevents spread to other systems. IT can begin incident response procedures.

questions.title: What is 'double extortion' ransomware?
options: Attackers steal data AND encrypt it, threatening to leak if not paid
questions.correct_answer: Attackers steal data AND encrypt it, threatening to leak if not paid
questions.explanation: Double extortion combines encryption with data theft, pressuring victims to pay even if they have backups.

questions.title: Why are offline backups important for ransomware protection?
options: Ransomware can encrypt connected backups - offline backups remain safe
questions.correct_answer: Ransomware can encrypt connected backups - offline backups remain safe
questions.explanation: Ransomware actively targets backup systems. Air-gapped/offline backups can't be encrypted remotely.

questions.title: What file types commonly spread ransomware?
questions.correct_answer: .exe, .js, .docm (macro-enabled), and .zip files
questions.explanation: Executable files, scripts, macro-enabled documents, and archives containing these are common vectors.

questions.title: What is 'Ransomware-as-a-Service' (RaaS)?
options: Criminal business model where developers sell/rent ransomware to affiliates
questions.correct_answer: Criminal business model where developers sell/rent ransomware to affiliates
questions.explanation: RaaS allows criminals without technical skills to launch ransomware attacks using tools from developers.

questions.title: How does ransomware typically spread within a network?
options: It can't spread to other computers
Using stolen credentials, network vulnerabilities, and lateral movement techniques
questions.correct_answer: Using stolen credentials, network vulnerabilities, and lateral movement techniques
questions.explanation: Once inside, ransomware uses various techniques to spread across the network before encrypting everything.

questions.title: What is a 'kill switch' in ransomware?
options: A way to destroy the encryption key
A built-in mechanism that stops the ransomware under certain conditions
questions.correct_answer: A built-in mechanism that stops the ransomware under certain conditions
questions.explanation: Some ransomware has kill switches (like WannaCry's domain check) that can halt the attack when triggered.

questions.title: Why is enabling macros in Microsoft Office documents risky?
options: Malicious macros can execute ransomware without additional user interaction
questions.correct_answer: Malicious macros can execute ransomware without additional user interaction
questions.explanation: Macro-enabled documents can contain code that downloads and executes ransomware automatically.

questions.title: What is the 3-2-1 backup rule?
options: 3 copies of data, 2 different storage types, 1 copy offsite/offline
questions.correct_answer: 3 copies of data, 2 different storage types, 1 copy offsite/offline
questions.explanation: 3-2-1 ensures redundancy: 3 copies, 2 media types, 1 offsite protects against various disaster scenarios.

questions.title: What is Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) exploitation in ransomware attacks?
options: Attackers exploit weak RDP credentials to gain access and deploy ransomware
questions.correct_answer: Attackers exploit weak RDP credentials to gain access and deploy ransomware
questions.explanation: Exposed RDP with weak credentials is a major ransomware entry point. Use strong passwords, MFA, and VPNs.

questions.title: What role does software patching play in ransomware prevention?
options: Critical - many ransomware attacks exploit known vulnerabilities with available patches
questions.correct_answer: Critical - many ransomware attacks exploit known vulnerabilities with available patches
questions.explanation: WannaCry and many others exploited unpatched systems. Regular patching closes known vulnerability gaps.

questions.title: What is 'dwell time' in ransomware attacks?
options: The time attackers spend in your network before deploying ransomware
questions.correct_answer: The time attackers spend in your network before deploying ransomware
questions.explanation: Modern attackers spend days or weeks inside networks, mapping systems and stealing data before encryption.

questions.title: Why might free ransomware decryption tools be available?
options: Security researchers find flaws in ransomware encryption or obtain keys
questions.correct_answer: Security researchers find flaws in ransomware encryption or obtain keys
questions.explanation: Sites like NoMoreRansom.org provide free decryptors when researchers crack ransomware or obtain keys.

questions.title: What is network segmentation's role in limiting ransomware damage?
options: It limits spread by isolating network sections so infected areas can't reach others
It has no effect on ransomware
questions.correct_answer: It limits spread by isolating network sections so infected areas can't reach others
questions.explanation: Segmentation contains outbreaks by preventing ransomware from spreading across the entire network.

questions.title: What should be included in a ransomware incident response plan?
options: Isolation procedures, communication plans, backup restoration steps, and reporting requirements
Nothing - just pay and move on
questions.correct_answer: Isolation procedures, communication plans, backup restoration steps, and reporting requirements
questions.explanation: Comprehensive plans ensure quick, coordinated responses that minimize damage and enable recovery.

questions.title: Why do ransomware attackers often demand cryptocurrency payments?
options: Cryptocurrency is harder to trace and doesn't require traditional banking
questions.correct_answer: Cryptocurrency is harder to trace and doesn't require traditional banking
questions.explanation: Cryptocurrency provides anonymity and doesn't require traceable banking systems.

name: USB & Physical Security
description: Learn about USB security risks, physical access threats, clean desk policies, and protecting against physical security breaches.

questions.title: You find a USB drive in the parking lot with a label 'Salary Info 2024'. What should you do?
options: Plug it into your computer to find the owner
Turn it in to security without connecting it to any device
Plug it into a public computer to check
questions.correct_answer: Turn it in to security without connecting it to any device
questions.explanation: USB baiting drops labeled drives hoping curiosity leads someone to connect an infected device.

questions.title: What is a 'USB Rubber Ducky'?
options: A device that poses as a keyboard to execute malicious commands rapidly
questions.correct_answer: A device that poses as a keyboard to execute malicious commands rapidly
questions.explanation: Rubber Ducky devices appear as USB drives but act as keyboards, typing malicious commands instantly.

questions.title: What is a 'clean desk policy'?
options: Ensuring sensitive materials are secured when not in use
questions.correct_answer: Ensuring sensitive materials are secured when not in use
questions.explanation: Clean desk policies prevent data exposure from visible documents, unlocked screens, or accessible devices.

questions.title: Why should you never charge your phone using unknown USB ports?
options: Malicious charging stations can install malware or steal data (juice jacking)
questions.correct_answer: Malicious charging stations can install malware or steal data (juice jacking)
questions.explanation: Juice jacking uses USB data connections in public chargers to infect phones or extract data.

questions.title: What is tailgating in physical security?
options: Following an authorized person through a secured entrance
questions.correct_answer: Following an authorized person through a secured entrance
questions.explanation: Tailgating bypasses access controls by following authorized personnel through secured doors.

questions.title: What is a 'USB Killer' device?
options: A device that delivers electrical surges to destroy computer hardware
questions.correct_answer: A device that delivers electrical surges to destroy computer hardware
questions.explanation: USB Killers look like flash drives but deliver voltage surges that physically destroy connected equipment.

questions.title: How should visitors be handled in a secure facility?
options: Escort them at all times and ensure they sign in/out and wear visible badges
questions.correct_answer: Escort them at all times and ensure they sign in/out and wear visible badges
questions.explanation: Visitor management prevents unauthorized access and maintains accountability for non-employees.

questions.title: Why are screen privacy filters important?
options: They prevent shoulder surfing by limiting screen visibility to direct viewing angles
questions.correct_answer: They prevent shoulder surfing by limiting screen visibility to direct viewing angles
questions.explanation: Privacy filters prevent people beside or behind you from reading your screen.

questions.title: What should you do if you see someone without a badge in a restricted area?
options: Politely ask if they need assistance and alert security if they can't verify authorization
questions.correct_answer: Politely ask if they need assistance and alert security if they can't verify authorization
questions.explanation: Challenge unknown individuals politely but firmly. Social engineers rely on people not questioning them.

questions.title: What is piggybacking vs. tailgating?
options: Piggybacking is with permission, tailgating is unauthorized following
questions.correct_answer: Piggybacking is with permission, tailgating is unauthorized following
questions.explanation: Piggybacking involves tricking someone into holding the door; tailgating is following without consent.

questions.title: How can you safely charge devices when traveling?
options: Use your own charger with an electrical outlet, or a USB data blocker
questions.correct_answer: Use your own charger with an electrical outlet, or a USB data blocker
questions.explanation: Your own charger or a data-blocking USB adapter prevents juice jacking attacks.

questions.title: Why should laptops be encrypted?
options: If stolen, encrypted data remains protected without the decryption key
questions.correct_answer: If stolen, encrypted data remains protected without the decryption key
questions.explanation: Full disk encryption protects data even if the physical device is stolen.

questions.title: What is a 'mantrap' in physical security?
options: A small room with two interlocking doors where only one opens at a time
questions.correct_answer: A small room with two interlocking doors where only one opens at a time
questions.explanation: Mantraps prevent tailgating by requiring individual authentication between two doors.

questions.title: What information can be exposed by an unlocked, unattended computer?
options: Email, files, network access, credentials saved in browsers, and more
questions.correct_answer: Email, files, network access, credentials saved in browsers, and more
questions.explanation: An unlocked computer gives access to everything the user can access - email, files, applications, network resources.

questions.title: What is the purpose of security cameras in offices?
options: Deterrence, evidence collection, and monitoring of access points
questions.correct_answer: Deterrence, evidence collection, and monitoring of access points
questions.explanation: Cameras deter bad actors, provide evidence of incidents, and help monitor sensitive areas.

questions.title: Why should you report lost or stolen devices immediately?
options: To enable remote wipe and prevent unauthorized access to company data
It's not important for small devices
questions.correct_answer: To enable remote wipe and prevent unauthorized access to company data
questions.explanation: Quick reporting allows IT to remotely wipe or lock devices before attackers can access data.

questions.title: What is a 'BadUSB' attack?
options: Malware that reprograms USB firmware to perform malicious actions
questions.correct_answer: Malware that reprograms USB firmware to perform malicious actions
questions.explanation: BadUSB reprograms the USB controller itself, making the device malicious at the hardware level.

questions.title: How should sensitive printed documents be handled?
options: Stack them neatly on your desk
Print only when needed, pick up immediately, and shred when done
Leave them in the printer for others to see
questions.correct_answer: Print only when needed, pick up immediately, and shred when done
questions.explanation: Print minimization, immediate retrieval, and proper disposal prevent document exposure.

questions.title: What is an 'air gap' in security?
options: Physical isolation of a system from unsecured networks
questions.correct_answer: Physical isolation of a system from unsecured networks
questions.explanation: Air-gapped systems have no network connection, protecting highly sensitive data from remote attacks.

questions.title: Why should you avoid using promotional USB drives from conferences?
options: They could be pre-infected with malware
questions.correct_answer: They could be pre-infected with malware
questions.explanation: Promotional drives can be compromised. Only use USB devices from trusted sources.

name: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
description: Understand different types of authentication factors, MFA implementation, and why it's crucial for account security.

questions.title: What are the three main categories of authentication factors?
options: Something you know, something you have, something you are
questions.correct_answer: Something you know, something you have, something you are
questions.explanation: Knowledge (passwords), possession (phone/token), and inherence (biometrics) are the three factor categories.

questions.title: Why is MFA more secure than password-only authentication?
options: Attackers need to compromise multiple independent factors, not just steal a password
questions.correct_answer: Attackers need to compromise multiple independent factors, not just steal a password
questions.explanation: MFA requires multiple independent proofs of identity, making compromise much harder.

questions.title: Which MFA method is considered most secure?
questions.correct_answer: Hardware security keys (like YubiKey)
questions.explanation: Hardware keys are phishing-resistant and can't be intercepted like SMS or email codes.

questions.title: Why is SMS-based MFA considered less secure than authenticator apps?
options: SMS can be intercepted through SIM swapping, SS7 attacks, or phone theft
questions.correct_answer: SMS can be intercepted through SIM swapping, SS7 attacks, or phone theft
questions.explanation: SMS messages can be intercepted through various attacks. Authenticator apps generate codes locally.

questions.title: What is a 'SIM swap' attack?
options: Attackers convince carriers to transfer your phone number to their SIM
questions.correct_answer: Attackers convince carriers to transfer your phone number to their SIM
questions.explanation: SIM swapping hijacks your phone number, allowing attackers to receive your SMS codes.

questions.title: How do authenticator apps (like Google Authenticator) generate codes?
options: They receive codes from the internet
They use time-based algorithms with a shared secret (TOTP)
They connect to the company's server
questions.correct_answer: They use time-based algorithms with a shared secret (TOTP)
questions.explanation: TOTP (Time-based One-Time Password) uses a shared secret and current time to generate codes offline.

questions.title: What should you do with MFA backup codes?
options: Store them securely offline in case you lose access to your MFA device
questions.correct_answer: Store them securely offline in case you lose access to your MFA device
questions.explanation: Backup codes are recovery options if you lose your MFA device. Store them securely but separately.

questions.title: What is biometric authentication?
options: Using unique physical characteristics like fingerprints or face recognition
questions.correct_answer: Using unique physical characteristics like fingerprints or face recognition
questions.explanation: Biometrics use unique physical traits (fingerprints, face, iris) as authentication factors.

questions.title: You receive an MFA code you didn't request. What should you do?
options: Ignore it - someone may be trying to access your account, consider changing your password
It's normal, use it next time
questions.correct_answer: Ignore it - someone may be trying to access your account, consider changing your password
questions.explanation: Unrequested codes indicate someone has your password and is trying to log in. Change your password.

questions.title: What is a 'push notification' MFA method?
options: An app sends a prompt to approve or deny a login attempt
questions.correct_answer: An app sends a prompt to approve or deny a login attempt
questions.explanation: Push notifications show login details and let you approve or deny with one tap.

questions.title: What is 'MFA fatigue' and why is it dangerous?
options: Attackers spam push notifications until the user approves one out of frustration
questions.correct_answer: Attackers spam push notifications until the user approves one out of frustration
questions.explanation: MFA bombing sends repeated prompts hoping users approve one to stop the notifications.

questions.title: What makes FIDO2/WebAuthn security keys phishing-resistant?
options: They cryptographically verify the website's identity and won't work on fake sites
questions.correct_answer: They cryptographically verify the website's identity and won't work on fake sites
questions.explanation: FIDO2 keys verify the actual website domain, refusing to authenticate on phishing sites.

questions.title: Why shouldn't you share MFA codes with anyone, including IT support?
options: Legitimate IT never needs your codes - this is a social engineering attack
questions.correct_answer: Legitimate IT never needs your codes - this is a social engineering attack
questions.explanation: No legitimate support personnel need your MFA codes. Anyone asking is likely an attacker.

questions.title: What is adaptive or risk-based authentication?
options: Systems that adjust authentication requirements based on risk signals
Using different passwords for different sites
Authentication that adapts to user preferences
questions.correct_answer: Systems that adjust authentication requirements based on risk signals
questions.explanation: Adaptive auth requires additional verification for unusual activity (new device, location, behavior).

questions.title: What should you do if you lose your phone with an authenticator app?
options: Use backup codes and set up MFA on a new device immediately
questions.correct_answer: Use backup codes and set up MFA on a new device immediately
questions.explanation: Use backup codes to regain access, then immediately set up MFA on a new device and revoke the old one.

questions.title: What is 'step-up authentication'?
options: Requiring additional verification for sensitive actions after initial login
questions.correct_answer: Requiring additional verification for sensitive actions after initial login
questions.explanation: Step-up auth requires extra verification (re-entering password, MFA) for high-risk actions like transfers.

questions.title: Which accounts should have MFA enabled as a priority?
options: Email, banking, social media, and any account with sensitive data
questions.correct_answer: Email, banking, social media, and any account with sensitive data
questions.explanation: Email is especially critical as it's used for password resets. All sensitive accounts need MFA.

questions.title: What is a 'passkey'?
options: A master key for all accounts
A passwordless authentication method using cryptographic keys stored on your device
A physical key for your computer
questions.correct_answer: A passwordless authentication method using cryptographic keys stored on your device
questions.explanation: Passkeys use device-stored cryptographic credentials, eliminating passwords while being phishing-resistant.

questions.title: Why is using the same phone for banking and SMS MFA codes potentially risky?
options: If your phone is compromised, attackers have access to both your banking app AND your MFA codes
questions.correct_answer: If your phone is compromised, attackers have access to both your banking app AND your MFA codes
questions.explanation: Phone compromise gives attackers access to both the app and the second factor, defeating MFA's purpose.

questions.title: What is the benefit of number-matching in push notification MFA?
options: Users must enter a displayed number, preventing accidental or fatigue-based approvals
questions.correct_answer: Users must enter a displayed number, preventing accidental or fatigue-based approvals
questions.explanation: Number matching requires entering a specific code, preventing MFA fatigue attacks and accidental approvals.

name: Business Email Compromise (BEC)
description: Recognize and prevent Business Email Compromise attacks, including CEO fraud, invoice manipulation, and account compromise.

questions.title: What is Business Email Compromise (BEC)?
options: Sophisticated scams where attackers pose as trusted parties to steal money or data
questions.correct_answer: Sophisticated scams where attackers pose as trusted parties to steal money or data
questions.explanation: BEC uses social engineering to impersonate executives, vendors, or partners for financial fraud.

questions.title: What is 'CEO fraud' in BEC attacks?
options: Attackers impersonating executives to request urgent wire transfers
questions.correct_answer: Attackers impersonating executives to request urgent wire transfers
questions.explanation: CEO fraud impersonates senior executives to pressure finance staff into urgent wire transfers.

questions.title: You receive an email from your CEO asking for an urgent wire transfer. What should you do first?
options: Verify the request through a different channel (phone call to known number)
questions.correct_answer: Verify the request through a different channel (phone call to known number)
questions.explanation: Always verify unusual requests via a separate channel. Attackers may have compromised email.

questions.title: What is a 'vendor email compromise' attack?
options: Attackers compromise or impersonate vendor accounts to redirect payments
questions.correct_answer: Attackers compromise or impersonate vendor accounts to redirect payments
questions.explanation: Attackers impersonate or hack vendor accounts to change payment details on legitimate invoices.

questions.title: Why do BEC attacks often succeed despite not containing malware?
options: They exploit human trust and bypass technical security controls
questions.correct_answer: They exploit human trust and bypass technical security controls
questions.explanation: BEC relies on social engineering rather than malware, so technical controls can't detect them.

questions.title: What red flag indicates a potential BEC email from an executive?
options: Request for secrecy or urgency about a financial transaction
questions.correct_answer: Request for secrecy or urgency about a financial transaction
questions.explanation: Requests for secrecy, urgency, or unusual financial actions are major BEC indicators.

questions.title: What is 'account takeover' in BEC?
options: Attackers gain control of legitimate email accounts to send fraudulent messages
questions.correct_answer: Attackers gain control of legitimate email accounts to send fraudulent messages
questions.explanation: Account takeover is when attackers compromise real accounts, making detection much harder.

questions.title: How do attackers typically prepare for BEC attacks?
options: Research via LinkedIn, company websites, and social engineering to understand targets
questions.correct_answer: Research via LinkedIn, company websites, and social engineering to understand targets
questions.explanation: BEC attackers research organizations thoroughly to craft convincing, targeted requests.

questions.title: What is the 'man-in-the-email' attack?
options: Attackers insert themselves into email conversations to redirect payments
questions.correct_answer: Attackers insert themselves into email conversations to redirect payments
questions.explanation: Attackers monitor or compromise email to insert themselves into ongoing transactions.

questions.title: A vendor emails that their bank account has changed. What should you do?
options: Verify through a known phone number BEFORE making any changes
questions.correct_answer: Verify through a known phone number BEFORE making any changes
questions.explanation: Payment change requests are common BEC tactics. Always verify via previously known contact information.

questions.title: What technical control helps prevent BEC?
options: Email authentication (SPF, DKIM, DMARC) and external email warnings
questions.correct_answer: Email authentication (SPF, DKIM, DMARC) and external email warnings
questions.explanation: Email authentication prevents spoofing; external sender warnings alert users to potential impersonation.

questions.title: Why might BEC emails come from look-alike domains?
options: Attackers register similar domains (company-inc.com vs company.com) to appear legitimate
questions.correct_answer: Attackers register similar domains (company-inc.com vs company.com) to appear legitimate
questions.explanation: Look-alike domains add legitimacy. Users often don't notice small domain differences.

questions.title: What process helps prevent unauthorized wire transfers?
options: Dual approval requirements and out-of-band verification for large transfers
No approval needed for small amounts
questions.correct_answer: Dual approval requirements and out-of-band verification for large transfers
questions.explanation: Multiple approvals and verification via different channels prevent single-point-of-failure fraud.

questions.title: What is 'gift card fraud' in BEC?
options: Attackers impersonate executives asking employees to buy and send gift card codes
questions.correct_answer: Attackers impersonate executives asking employees to buy and send gift card codes
questions.explanation: Gift card scams are BEC variants requesting untraceable gift card purchases.

questions.title: An email from your 'boss' asks you to buy gift cards for client gifts. They're traveling and can't call. What should you do?
options: This is likely a scam - verify through official channels regardless of excuses
questions.correct_answer: This is likely a scam - verify through official channels regardless of excuses
questions.explanation: Excuses preventing verification (traveling, in meetings, phone broken) are classic BEC tactics.

questions.title: What role does timing play in BEC attacks?
options: Attackers strike when targets are distracted, rushed, or executives are traveling
questions.correct_answer: Attackers strike when targets are distracted, rushed, or executives are traveling
questions.explanation: BEC attacks often coincide with executive travel, quarter-end rushes, or other high-pressure periods.

questions.title: What is 'attorney impersonation' in BEC?
options: Attackers pose as lawyers handling confidential matters requiring urgent payment
questions.correct_answer: Attackers pose as lawyers handling confidential matters requiring urgent payment
questions.explanation: Attorney impersonation adds authority and secrecy pressure to urgent payment requests.

questions.title: Why is BEC particularly dangerous for finance and HR departments?
options: They handle sensitive data and financial transactions that attackers target
questions.correct_answer: They handle sensitive data and financial transactions that attackers target
questions.explanation: Finance processes payments; HR handles sensitive employee data - both are prime BEC targets.

questions.title: What should companies do after falling victim to BEC?
options: Immediately contact banks to recall transfers and report to law enforcement
questions.correct_answer: Immediately contact banks to recall transfers and report to law enforcement
questions.explanation: Quick action can sometimes recover funds. Report to FBI's IC3 and implement lessons learned.

questions.title: What employee training is most effective against BEC?
options: Verification procedures, recognizing social engineering, and a culture where questioning unusual requests is encouraged
questions.correct_answer: Verification procedures, recognizing social engineering, and a culture where questioning unusual requests is encouraged
questions.explanation: BEC prevention requires training on verification processes and empowering employees to question unusual requests.

name: Secure Browsing & Downloads
description: Learn safe web browsing practices, how to identify safe vs malicious websites, and secure download habits.

questions.title: What does a padlock icon in your browser's address bar indicate?
options: The website is completely safe and trustworthy
The connection is encrypted (HTTPS), but the site could still be malicious
questions.correct_answer: The connection is encrypted (HTTPS), but the site could still be malicious
questions.explanation: HTTPS means encrypted connection, not that the site is safe. Phishing sites can have HTTPS too.

questions.title: You want to download a popular software. Where should you get it?
options: The software's official website or official app store
questions.correct_answer: The software's official website or official app store
questions.explanation: Official sources are verified. Third-party sites may bundle malware with legitimate software.

questions.title: What is 'typosquatting' in web security?
options: Registering domains with common typos to catch users who mistype URLs
questions.correct_answer: Registering domains with common typos to catch users who mistype URLs
questions.explanation: Typosquatting catches typing errors (googel.com instead of google.com) to deliver malware or phishing.

questions.title: Your browser warns that a website's certificate is invalid. What should you do?
options: Don't visit the site - certificate errors can indicate attacks or compromised sites
questions.correct_answer: Don't visit the site - certificate errors can indicate attacks or compromised sites
questions.explanation: Certificate errors may indicate man-in-the-middle attacks or compromised servers. Don't proceed.

questions.title: Why should you keep your browser updated?
options: Updates patch security vulnerabilities that attackers exploit
questions.correct_answer: Updates patch security vulnerabilities that attackers exploit
questions.explanation: Browser updates fix security vulnerabilities. Outdated browsers are major attack targets.

questions.title: What are browser extensions' security risks?
options: Malicious extensions can access all your browsing data and credentials
questions.correct_answer: Malicious extensions can access all your browsing data and credentials
questions.explanation: Extensions have broad permissions. Malicious ones can steal data, inject ads, or hijack sessions.

questions.title: What is a 'drive-by download'?
options: Malware that downloads without user knowledge just by visiting a webpage
questions.correct_answer: Malware that downloads without user knowledge just by visiting a webpage
questions.explanation: Drive-by downloads exploit browser or plugin vulnerabilities to install malware without clicks.

questions.title: Before downloading software, what should you check?
options: Publisher reputation, reviews, official source, and file type
questions.correct_answer: Publisher reputation, reviews, official source, and file type
questions.explanation: Verify the source is legitimate, read reviews, and ensure file types match expectations.

questions.title: What is the purpose of browser sandboxing?
options: Isolating web content to prevent malware from affecting the operating system
questions.correct_answer: Isolating web content to prevent malware from affecting the operating system
questions.explanation: Sandboxing contains potential threats, preventing web-based attacks from escaping the browser.

questions.title: A website asks to enable Flash Player. What should you do?
options: Refuse - Flash Player was discontinued in 2020 and is often used for malware delivery
questions.correct_answer: Refuse - Flash Player was discontinued in 2020 and is often used for malware delivery
questions.explanation: Flash Player is discontinued. Any prompt to install/enable it is attempting to install malware.

questions.title: What should you do if a website says your computer is infected?
options: Ignore it - legitimate security warnings come from your installed antivirus, not websites
Provide your credit card to fix it
questions.correct_answer: Ignore it - legitimate security warnings come from your installed antivirus, not websites
questions.explanation: Websites cannot scan your computer. These are scareware tactics to install malware.

questions.title: What is 'DNS over HTTPS' (DoH)?
options: Encrypting DNS queries to prevent eavesdropping on your browsing
questions.correct_answer: Encrypting DNS queries to prevent eavesdropping on your browsing
questions.explanation: DoH encrypts DNS lookups, preventing ISPs and attackers from seeing which sites you visit.

questions.title: Why should you be cautious with public Wi-Fi?
options: Attackers can intercept unencrypted traffic and create fake hotspots
questions.correct_answer: Attackers can intercept unencrypted traffic and create fake hotspots
questions.explanation: Public Wi-Fi enables traffic interception and evil twin attacks. Use VPN for sensitive activities.

questions.title: What is a 'watering hole attack'?
options: Compromising websites frequently visited by target groups
questions.correct_answer: Compromising websites frequently visited by target groups
questions.explanation: Watering hole attacks infect websites that specific target groups frequent, like industry forums.

questions.title: What should you check before entering credentials on a website?
options: URL is correct, connection is HTTPS, and you navigated there directly
questions.correct_answer: URL is correct, connection is HTTPS, and you navigated there directly
questions.explanation: Verify the exact URL, ensure HTTPS, and access sensitive sites by typing URLs directly.

questions.title: A pop-up claims you've won a prize. To claim it, you need to enter personal information. What should you do?
options: Close the pop-up immediately - this is a scam
questions.correct_answer: Close the pop-up immediately - this is a scam
questions.explanation: Pop-up prize claims are always scams designed to harvest personal information.

questions.title: What is browser fingerprinting?
options: Tracking users by collecting unique browser and system characteristics
questions.correct_answer: Tracking users by collecting unique browser and system characteristics
questions.explanation: Fingerprinting identifies users by combining browser settings, plugins, fonts, and other attributes.

questions.title: Why should you avoid saving passwords in your browser for sensitive accounts?
options: Browser password storage is less secure than dedicated password managers
questions.correct_answer: Browser password storage is less secure than dedicated password managers
questions.explanation: Dedicated password managers offer better security features than browser-based storage.

questions.title: What is the safest practice when downloading email attachments?
options: Verify the sender, scan with antivirus, and be suspicious of unexpected files
questions.correct_answer: Verify the sender, scan with antivirus, and be suspicious of unexpected files
questions.explanation: Email attachments are common malware vectors. Verify before opening any attachments.

questions.title: What does 'incognito mode' or 'private browsing' actually protect?
options: Local history only - websites, ISPs, and employers can still track you
questions.correct_answer: Local history only - websites, ISPs, and employers can still track you
questions.explanation: Private browsing only prevents local history storage. You're not anonymous to websites, networks, or ISPs.
